title: Raiders' Norton trying to keep Hayden's confidence high
text:
Raiders' Norton trying to keep Hayden's confidence high By Jimmy Durkin Posted: 10/22/2015 02:53:43 PM PDT Updated: 10/22/2015 04:58:26 PM PDT Raiders news on Facebook ALAMEDA -- DJ Hayden would be happy to relive more moments like his first meeting with San Diego Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers. 
Hayden intercepted Rivers in the end zone late in the fourth quarter in that meeting during his rookie season in 2013, the last time the Raiders beat their in-state rival in the AFC West. 
Moments like that have been rare for the former No. 12 overall pick. He has only one other interception in 18 games since, that coming early in an eventual blowout loss to the Denver Broncos last season. 
Too often, Hayden's been mentioned for his struggles. In just 10 games last season, he was beaten for six touchdowns and quarterbacks had a 121.6 passer rating throwing his way, according to Pro Football Focus. He's already allowed three touchdowns and a 119.3 rating in five games this season. Oakland Raiders' D.J. Hayden (25) and Oakland Raiders' Nate Allen (20) react to a call against Hayden during their game against the Arizona Cardinals in the second quarter of their NFL preseason game at O.co Coliseum in Oakland, Calif, on Sunday, Aug. 30, 2015. The call was overturned. (Nhat V. Meyer/Bay Area News Group) ( Nhat V. Meyer ) 
Still, Hayden feels like he and the Raiders defense are growing and improving. 
"We're just overall getting better and better each week," Hayden said. "Whether it's tackling, attacking the ball in the air ... we're getting better." 
Defensive coordinator Ken Norton Jr. says he's seeing improvement from Hayden. 
"Early on, you saw balls get thrown deep on him," Norton said. "Now, you see those deep balls, the number of times are getting smaller. He's making plays. He's covering people. His coverage is a lot tighter." 
That's not to say Hayden has fully turned any corners. He's allowed a reception of 20-plus yards in all but one game, and in the 16-7 loss to the Broncos that preceded the bye, he was beaten deep when he bit on a double move by Emmanuel Sanders and saw him scoot by for a 45-yard gain. But on the seven other times he was targeted, Denver receivers made just four catches for 33 yards. Advertisement 
That Broncos game marked the first time all season he wasn't credited with any missed tackles and, as a team, that's an area that has improved. After having 31 missed tackles the first two games -- during which they allowed a total of 70 points -- they've missed only 22 tackles the past three while allowing an average of 19.3 points. 
Hayden's starting spot figures to be tenuous in a few weeks if Nate Allen returns from his knee injury. Allen, on the short-term injured reserve, could begin practicing in two weeks and is eligible to return Nov. 15 against Minnesota. 
That would allow TJ Carrie to slide back to cornerback, where David Amerson seems in good shape to maintain a starting spot. Hayden could be relegated to a spot in the Raiders' nickel defense. 
Some of Norton's complimentary comments about Hayden may have to do with a continued effort to instill confidence in the third-year player, who was drafted No. 12 overall by Reggie McKenzie in the 2013 draft. 
"For young players, confidence is really important," Norton said while discussing Hayden. "You really have to find a lot of the positive things they are doing and really build their confidence. His repetitions are high, his skill is getting really good. He's really growing into one of the better corners in the league." 
That might be going a step too far with the praise, but the Raiders could sure use another outing like that rookie performance against San Diego. That stands statistically as his best outing as a pro. He was targeted five times and allowed just one catch for 16 yards, giving Rivers just a 0.2 rating going his way -- by far the best game of Hayden's career.
